death: ^You are dead, and your story ends here.
start: ^You are the scion of the Elbéar tribe and your father, the chieftain, is dying. He has led the tribe through a period of unprecedented prosperity and safety, and with his impending death, the Shamans are auguring the end of an era. The Elders look to you, his only child, for new leadership.

b: ^ You, too, have felt the wind changing, and despite the circumstances you feel excitement stir in you.
^ Becoming chieftain is a heavy burden, especially considering the circumstances. But in your heart of hearts, you have looked forward to it.
^ Your father was blessed to live in uninteresting times; you doubt the same will be true of your reign.
^ It is something you have been groomed for your entire life; you simply did not expect it so soon.

start: ^You are not chieftain yet, however, and you will have a long way to go before you earn the Elbéar’s trust. To earn it, you must leave the Corral and make a name for yourself in the City.

loop: ^The Elders wish to speak to you.
^An old friend has sent a message.

c-0: ^Their tent is stitched of ancient cloth; each patch taken from the clothes of an Elder after they pass away.

b: ^ After an Elder dies, their family gets to squabble over which piece of cloth is donated to the tent. You wonder how many strips of loincloth it contains.
^ Somewhere in the middle remains the cloak of the First Elders; the material so strong it has never been replaced. Or so they say.
^ An old axiom says: all is well as long as the Elders complain of a lack of room in the tent. A people where none have time to grow old is not a people that will survive long.
^ You wonder if it is really true; wouldn’t cloth make terrible tent-material? Still, it is a good story.

elderTalk: ^Inside, you are met with a cacophony of voices.

b: ^ Like brushfowl during mating season; except mating season is long passed for these birds.
^ The Elders are long past caring about pomp and ceremony, which is refreshing in its own way.
^ You stop at the entrance, feeling awkward. The Elders ignore you.
^ Few pay attention to your arrival.

elderTalk: ^Your baba escapes a clutch of chatting elders and approaches you.

b: ^ She pinches your cheek; a pre-emptive punishment, she says, for whatever you’ve done or are about to do.
^ She frowns and shakes her head when she sees you.
^ She smiles when she sees you, but you sense something is off.

elderTalk: ^She shushes the other Elders; as they quiet down, you realize your baba is probably the most powerful person in the Tribe right now. Every one of the Elders in this tent are the matriarchs and patriarchs of their own little clans; and they all listen to your baba.
^If you are to become chieftain, you will have to work for it.
^You have lived your whole life here in the safety of the Corral: not once have you left beyond its gates. When the time comes – and by the Bozes it will – the people will not follow you.

b: ^ You want to protest: it wasn’t for a lack of trying that you stayed in the Corral; but that will only earn your ears a boxing, so you look down instead and shrug.
^ You bristle a bit: there are few things you would have wanted more than to go explore, but you were forbidden.
^ Your ears grow red with shame, but the injustice of it also stings: you did what was expected of you, and that was to stay here, in safety.
^ A pit opens in your stomach – it is truly happening. The responsibility suddenly feels overwhelming.

elderTalk: ^'Trust. Trust is the most important thing you have. Your every action must build trust.' She continues, her eyes hard as battle-spoken Clay.
elderLoop: ^Ask what you can do to build trust.

c-0: ^'Lead a wercru. Gather the members yourself and go out into the world. Your every action will be watched. When you return here, the tales of your deeds – good and bad – will spread among the people. A wercru is small…but it is a good start.'
c-1: ^She shakes her head. 'The Crescent-Lights can mean anything. There is no need to spread fear. Not yet. Not now.'

b: ^ You shrug. The Crescent-Lights seem to mean different things to every Shaman anyway, and frequently and miraculously changed meaning before and after dinner.
^ You frown. The Crescent-Lights could predict many things: disease, storms, death. What were they predicting now?
^ You nod. If you are not meant to know yet, then you are not meant to know. You trust the wise men and women to tell you when the time comes.
^ You feel a stir of worry; it is not like your baba to hide unpleasant news. But these are uncommon times.

c-2: ^'Hold on a second.' Your baba stops you. 'You think you can just walk out of the Corral? Here.'
^She gives you a small, palm-sized claywork device.
^'This will open the gate for you and your wercru.'
^You look at it; an ombrascope – a tool used by the Tribe to communicate with the City through shadows and light.
^'This one is virginal.  You will need to teach it our sigils.'

b: ^ You can barely suppress a grin of excitement. Having an ombrascope opens up the whole city to adventure – not just the Corral and its environs. But then your grin freezes; your baba would not give this away unless the situation truly is as serious as she says.

^ You hold up the ombrascope to the light, seeing through it the intricate claywork that would duplicate the glyphs that bound the City. They were rare – and immensely powerful. Your baba’s gift was no toy.
^ The ombrascope feels heavy in your hand; solid. You recognize it for what it is: a weapon against a capricious and cruel City. A way to open paths and assert control.

^ You accept the gift, with some measure of surprise. Ombrascopes are rare, rare and powerful. Your baba giving you one is both a sign of trust – and a sign that the time to hide from your responsibilities truly is past.

c-2: ^With the ombrascope in hand, you duck out of the tent, back into the light. You will need to teach it the sigils for the Corral entrance; the gatekeeper would know them.

b: ^You meet Fayni behind her family’s shop, where they keep the bric-a-brac that even Fayni’s parents couldn’t trade. Normally the image of calm, she looks uncommonly antsy.
^ You consider asking her if she’s found another ‘Shadow’ stealing, but decide against it. She might just punch you this time.
^ You nod at her, giving her a moment to collect her thoughts.
^ You tense up when you see her expression.
^ You decide not to pay any attention to it, greeting her as casually as you can.
^'I heard you are leaving the Corral. I want to come with you. Please?'

^You are surprised: the Vender family never seems to run out of things for Fayni to do, whether it’s manning the trading stall, doing endless inventory on their stores, or negotiating deals with anyone walking in through the Corral gates. It seems unlikely they’d be able to spare her. You tell her as much, and she gives you an annoyed glare.
^'I’m done being an errand girl. I will never learn anything about the real City unless I leave. I am joining your wercru, whether you’ll have me or not.'
^That’s not really how that works, but you’ve known each other since you were children; she will not be denied.
^'There's something else too. You know how we trade in stuff the scavengers bring in? Scrap, the Clayworkers call it.'
^'I noticed something about the Scrap. But I need more of it to be...to be sure.'
^'And the only place to find Scrap is out there. So...if you have the time for it...'
^Curious. If there is anyone who is not a Clayworker yet knows something about Scrap, it would be Fayni and her family. It sounds like a task for a wercru, either way.
^'I'll give you a tablet with what I know when we leave.'
^'But I'm coming no matter what, just so you know.'
^ You immediately give her the role of quartermaster, in charge of inventorying the stores.
^She rolls her eyes at you. 'I was going to do that anyway, kuratz.'
^ You welcome her with open arms. Fayni always understood you. She will be a valuable ally.
^ You hesitate, but only for a moment. Fayni is not like other hawkers; she has honor.
^ Fayni is one of your oldest friends – travelling with her will be like bringing a bit of the Corral with you.
^She says she’ll get her things and wait for you at the Corral gate.
^As you leave you see her take a deep breath, hardening herself for the conversation she is going to have with her parents.
^Valfrig meets you near the entrance to the Shaman’s enclave. Just a tenday ago he got his marks, and you can tell his face is still sore. But the tattoos are healing nicely.
^ You know half the unmarried women (and some of the married) in the Corral felt a sting of desperation when Valfrig finally took his Shaman vows. Celibacy, and all that.
^ You are happy for him, and a little jealous. As a Shaman, his main task will now be the gathering, dissemination and interpretation of knowledge.
^ Despite knowing him half your life, his transition into the full mysteries of Shamanhood makes you feel slightly uneasy in his presence.
^ You wonder if you should treat him differently now; but it is hard to see past the boy you grew up with, even if he is no longer a boy
^'You are putting together a wercru, yes?' He says, excitement shining in his eyes. 'I have to come. The Council is handing out assignments, and there is an open position for ‘Cartographer’. Please?'
^ It is impossible to say no to him when he looks at you with those hopeful eyes.
^ You were hoping to get at least one Shaman to join your wercru: Valfrig would make an excellent addition.
^ To go outside the Corral without a Shaman is like walking backwards into a fight. Having a shaman is like walking backwards into a fight, except someone telling you it is a good idea.
^ Having an old friend like Valfrig along, especially with his skills, would be invaluable.
^You accept, and he lights up and gives you a fierce hug before you have time to protest.
^'Now: I know the Elders probably have a task for you, but hear me out.'
^'The Loretellers speak of a place in the ruins that contains a map of the City as it existed before the Hunger.'
^'It is the size of a wall, and protected by a fierce guardian.'
^'I must see if it is true. I must make a copy of it. Please - if you find the time...'
^You are not really sure what the use of an ancient map of the City might be, but Valfrig sounds so excited that you can do little but nod.
^'Thank you! I will give you the details when we head out!'
^Then he rushes off – to tell the Council, to pack his things. You shout after him to meet you at the Corral gates. You hope he heard.

^You find Barr at the training grounds. She is in the middle of a shouting match with a man two heads taller than her, who visibly shrinks away from her words. Nearby, a young boy is rubbing his head, a healer kneeling next to him. The other braves have all stopped their training, watching the exchange. It seems the warrior had been a bit too rough when training with the boy, and accidentally hit him on the head, knocking him out for a moment. Barr is giving him a piece of her mind.
^ You chuckle and lean against a well-worn training pole, enjoying the show.
^ While Barr rightfully hides the warrior, you check with the healer. A blow to the head can be very dangerous. Luckily, the boy seems all right, although he will need to be kept under guard.
^ You restrain yourself from joining in: Barr can handle herself; if she needed your help, she would ask.
^ You stay on the sidelines and wait. When Barr gets going, she will not be stopped.
^The warrior finally escapes when the training master comes over, even if he simply keeps berating him. Barr comes over, her stride purposeful as always.
^'I heard you are putting together a wercru – I want in.' She says, matter-of-factly. 'It is a dangerous City. You will need a good blade by your side.'
^ As children, you would attempt to scale the walls and escape at least once a week. This time, you could simply walk through the gate.
^ You frown. Barr is known for her recklessness. But then, every wecru does need warriors.
^ You feel a surge of pride: that Barr, one of the tribe’s best young braves, would pledge herself to your crew? It was a good feeling.
^You bump elbows on it, and Barr promises to meet you at the gate before you leave. She tries to hide it, but you can tell from the smile tugging at her mouth she is genuinely excited.

^When you arrive at the latrines, Chi is at first nowhere to be found. The stink is what alerts you to her presence. She was caught a season ago, stealing from a caravan; her punishment was predictable, if awful.
^ You always felt sorry for her; like a fly accidentally caught in shit. But despite her predicament, she is always full of funny stories.
^ Outsiders are technically outlaws; outside of the rules that govern crime and punishment in the tribe. The caravan master could have killed her on the spot – latrine duty was a mercy.
^ You have to admit however she has performed her new duties without too many complaints; as far as you are concerned, she has paid her dues.
^'I heard you are leaving.' Under the dirt and sweat shines a desperation. 'Please – take me with you. I know what it is like out there, I can help you. If I have to fill in one more hole…'

^You know she is technically free; her debt has been paid. But in the Corral she gets meals, companionship, safety – even if the only way she currently has to pay for it is by shovelling shit. Joining a wercru, no matter how dangerous, would be a vast improvement. And she is the only one you know who has actually been outside…
^You tell her to clean up, and meet you by the gate. She lights up.
^You cause a stir as you enter the Clayworker enclave; the workers stop what they are doing, touching their foreheads lightly in respect. Your father was one of them, and is dying like one of them.
^ In other words, like a fool. Few Clayworkers live to be older than fifty seasons.
^ You appreciate the thought, but you cannot help but feel there is something wrong with a profession that kills all of its workers.
^ You feel a swell of emotion constrict your throat, and nod back, like your father taught you.
^ You look down and hurry your steps. You did not come here to think of your father.

^Jaerd is by his worktable. In front of him is a coin of black clay that he is manipulating with a long caliper. When he sees you coming he stops and gets up, removing his eye-glass and gloves to elbow-bump you.
^'I heard you are putting together a wercru. I was hoping to join.' Jaerd smells of vitriol and sprit of niter. His skin glows with particulate matter. 'I need to replenish my stores of Clay.'

^You wonder if the Order will allow him to leave, but he assures you he has already been given the permission. Clayworkers, like Shamans, function under different hierarchies. You are familiar to some of them, through your father, but you have come to view them as even more arcane than the Council’s.
^He agrees to meet you by the Corral gate, together with all of his equipment.
^'I will need a cart for my chemicals.' He adds.
^Fayni catches up with you as you head towards the gate. The dark look on her face discourages any further questions, but she does hand you a tablet with some notes. A potential wercru task?
^[Fayni is a Pactmaker – as long as she is with you, she will boost your Pactmaker skill.]
^Valfrig is already waiting for you as you leave, wearing a heavy traveller’s robe, satchel full of maps by his side. He excitedly begins telling you about all the places he wants to go to first.
^[Valfrig is a Shaman – someone who knows the secrets of the City. He will join your other Shamans whenever they are needed.]

^ Barr saunters up to you as you prepare to leave; obsidian blade at her belt, forklance on her back, all lamellar and war paint. [Barr is a warrior and tactician – while she is with you she will boost your Warchief skill.]

^ Chi catches up to you, blissfully clean. She looks ready for a long journey, and excited to leave. [Chi is a wanderer. Her advice will help you find unconventional solutions to problems, boosting your Trickster skill.]
^ When Jaerd sees you he hoists his pack up – laden with all the tools of his trade. He wobbles a little. [Jaerd is a Clayworker – skilled with manipulating and working clay.]

prepareLeave: ^Your first order of business will be gathering the rest of your wercru. You head for the Crupit.
GetCorralSigil: ^You head to the gate with your ombrascope. The Watchman greets you somberly, and takes your ombrascope. Teaching claywork is usually the purvey of Clayworkers, but ombrascopes are different; if a crew leader should come across a new sigil in the City, it is vital they can record it even if they do not have a Clayworker with them. The Watchman speaks the words, and the ombrascope clicks to life, a beam of claylight that flickers a pattern of light on every surface it can find.

b: ^ Somehow you feel its curiosity; like a child, prodding and pressing at something new, and then learning to mimic it.
^ You marvel at the intricacy involved in the process, the endlessly complex machinations inside the small device that, somehow, ca capture patterns and light for later use.

^ You are intensely aware of the honor being bestowed upon you; ombrascopes are a rare and valuable tool, handed down from the ancients, and every new one created – like this one – is the result of countless weeks of toil by dozens of Clayworkers.
^ You stare in fascination at the flickering lights;  they change and adapt to every crevice and crease in your clothes, trying to find the glyph-patterns it was meant to absorb and learn.

GetCorralSigil: ^ The Watchman brings out a small, simple, smooth rock – a keystone –  upon which has been carved the sigil that opens the Corral. He lets the ombrascope’s light caress it until it seems to somehow ‘find’ it – focusing its beam more and more until the shadow-and-light from the ombrascope correspond entirely to the glyph on the keystone. Then he whispers one more command, and the ombrascope freezes for a moment – and then it shuts off.
^The Watchman puts away the keystone and hands you back your ombrascope.
^'It is your duty to gather any sigils you can find – remember that. Bring them back to us – they may one day save the whole tribe.'
^Ask if he can teach your ombrascope additional sigils.

c-0: ^'Yes, but my oma told me not to. She said you need to prove yourself. All you get for free is the one that gets you out of the gate.'
^He glances at the small crowd of people who seem to be following you wherever you go.

b: ^ You have a feeling you might be able to wrangle something from him if you come back later, with less of an audience.

firstRecruitementStart: ^You have never completed the wercru recruiting ceremony yourself, but you have watched it many times. You look now for the first time from the platform as the Crupit slowly fills with those who are interested; many more than usual, but then you know many of them are only there to watch, with no intention of joining.
^The Pitchief stands up and, with a booming voice, declares a new wercru is being formed, and that it is looking for volunteers.
^'The crew lead promises to feed all who join!' The Pitchief declares, to scattered applause. 'But what do they promise to pay?'
^You step forward, and the Crupit goes quiet.

b: ^ You strike a pose; this part is a performance, a show; they look at you, ready to be entertained enough to risk their lives for you.
^ You look at the faces below – your people – in awe of the fact that so many have shown up, ready to consider risking their lives for you.
^ How many times haven’t you stood down there, wishing you would be allowed to volunteer? You swell with pride, seeing how many of your people have shown up, ready to risk their lives.

firstRecruitementEnd: ^You tell your story as best you can: who you are, where you came from, who your father and mother are, and what you intend. It is a good story, a rare story. Many listen with rapt attention. But many, you notice, are less than impressed. You are young, you are unproven, your story – although heartfelt – is like the story of a child. An invention, a fantasy. Payment is traditionally in stories, or the promise thereof, and yours is sorely lacking.

^Nonetheless, once you finish, a sizeable number of tribesmen remain, making a line towards the Pitchief. She marks down their names and occupation symbolically, erasing each name from the tablet as she finishes. When she is done, she hands you the tablet, and you erase the last name on it and write your own. Then you note the number of your crew, and hand it back to her.
^For the first time, you have a wercru. They look at you with eager eyes, ready to leave at once. You return to the main street of the Corral, considering your next move.

b: ^You head back to the Watchman, finding him in much the same place you saw him last. This time, you do not have a crowd following you, and he seems less reserved.
^'Let me guess. The City is not letting you in.' He chuckles.
^'There is a set of Sigils we usually teach all new ombrascopes. One of them will let you enter the City's white ruins and plunder their riches.'
^'But you're not going to give it away for free, are you?' Chi mutters, loud enough for you to hear.
^'I just need a little something in exchange. My oma will never let me hear the end of it otherwise.'
^'You have a wercru, yes? I happen to need some work done. I'll need ten strong backs for the whole day.'
^You return to find your tribesmen all waiting patiently for you, next to a beaming Watchman.
^'They did an excellent job, much obliged.' He looks pleased. 'Follow me.'
^You head back to the Watchman. After a brief chat it becomes apparent he still needs those ten men.

GetRuins_InteriorSigil: ^ Lend him ten tribesmen for a day

b: ^You appeal to his sense of decency, the urgency and importance of your mission, and
^ throw in the suggestion your baba could make his oma's life very uncomfortable.
^ remind him of what he said about the Sigils being a common good.
^ urge him to keep the common good of the tribe in mind.
^'Fine. You've convinced me. She'll just have to make do...'
^He listens to you, but none of your arguments seem to make a dent.

GiveTribesmen: ^The tribesmen trudge up to the Watchman, clearly a little disappointed their work does not extend to outside the Corral today. You tell the rest of your wercru to take the day off.
Success: ^The Watchman leads you into his stack, cool compared to the outside. Few choose to live inside, but the Watchman is different. He meets every day with the Boze-bots in his tower after all; some say he even speaks their language.
^You glance around. Dirty clothes, dishes, wicker chairs and an old carved-wooden table. The den of a bachelor. He is digging through an old-world chest, hard metal.

^After a moment, he finds the keystone he was looking for. He brings it to you and you show it to your ombrascope. The light searches the groves on the keystone, memorizing the sigil. You thank him and leave.

b: ^ You ask your tribesmen afterwards what he wanted done. They tell you they spent the day raising a greenhouse for the Watchman's oma.

MainStory00Success: ^Your baba emerges from the crowd of Elders, a smile on her wrinkled face.
^'But don't get complacent. This is only the beginning.'
^You return to your crew and tell them they can return to their families - for now.

b: ^Your clayworkers manage to wring the most out of the scrap.
^You do what you can, but you cannot quite tease all of the Clay out of the scrap. You leave the leftovers for later.
^Your Clayworkers do what they can, but much of  the Clay in the scrap remains untouched. Perhaps they can work on it again later.
^There is not enough scrap to produce any Clay yet.
^You grimly make note of the rations added.
^You harvest the rich bounty of arrowroot and more.
^What is worse, you find almost nothing to eat.
^Your tribesmen return with various bits and bobs, ready to be melted down for Clay.
^Your tribesmen return with what they can carry, but you already have as much scrap as you can carry. [Turn your Scrap into Clay in your camp!].

ScavengeClayLose: ^There is nothing there. Just dust and waste.

s0: ^You shout and look, but find no trace of them.
s1: ^You find traces of blood and clothing, but no bodies.
s3: ^You find them, dead, at the bottom of a cliff; an accident?
s4: ^You look, but they have been swallowed - perhaps literally - by the City.

ScavengeFumbled: ^ The City is dangerous, and a single lapse in concentration can spell your death.
ScavengePeople: ^Convince the tribesmen to join your wercru.
^Convince some of their warriors to join your wercru.

c-3: ^You make your greetings and then part ways.

ScavengePeopleWin: ^Your new crewmembers join you, eager to be on their way.
ScavengePeopleLose: ^Few seem interested, despite your best attempts.

b: ^The stories of your misfortunes are soon spread through the Corral. Although no-one expects you to succeed at everything you do, your actions are closely scrutinized.
^This time, you did not make a good impression.
^The stories of your misfortunes mix with the stories of your bravery and leadership, and in the end the bad and the good become nearly interchangeable.
^Although in the process, some of your acts of bravery are also forgotten.

debugTravelOptions: ^You prepare to leave once more. Where do you go?
district1: ^[Home] Your home. A place of safety and community for everyone in the Tribe.
district2: ^[Park/Engine] A lush park, overgrown with vines.
district3: ^[Disassembler] The home of the Drones, who live inside the buildings.
district4: ^[Factory]An industrial district. In the middle squats massive building surrounded on all sides by walls.
district5: ^[Final] The ugly heart of the City. Avoid.
district8: ^[War Golem] A former battlefield - a blasted place that no-one goes to.
district9: ^[The Dig] The financial district, filled with massive, collapsed skyscrapers.

b: ^Text for the -very first- time you visit.
^Text that comes if the location was created over 5 days ago.
^Text that shows if the location is very close to the edge. Use together with creation time to check if the reason is because it was newly created or because it is about to be destroyed.

c-0: ^Start a timer with a start time of 0 and an end time of 5, that goes to the stitch timeEnded when finished.

timeEnded: ^This is the stitch we go to once the timer ends. Let's reward the player!

b: ^[A new location has been revealed on the map!]
^[You can no longer visit this location!]
^Warchiefs lead the tribe in war. They are strong combatants and leaders, honor-bound to protect their fellow tribesmen.
^Pactmakers are diplomats and traders, capable of bridging the gap between people without resorting to violence.
^A less traditional kind of leader, Tricksters go against the grain, coming up with novel solutions to old problems.

c-5: ^Your are an unknown in your tribe: your first task will be to build trust in your leadership. Lead a wercru, gather Tales of Bravery, and tell them to the Elders to build Trust!

b: ^Choose a starting Companion. [Companions are friends who will always follow you and who will give bonuses to stats. They all have their own stories as well. You can find more Companions during your story.]
^Fayni comes from a family of traders, and has always had a way with words. Like you, she has never left the Corral. [Pactmaker +1]
^Valfrig is a Shaman; sages, scientists, teachers and storytellers. His speciality is cartography - a lost art in the City. [Shamans +1]
^Barr is one of the best, and bravest, warriors in the Corral. She will be able to advice you in all matters pertaining to War. [Warchief +1]
^Chi is a Wanderer; someone from outside the Elbéar tribe. Although a thief, she knows the world outside the Corral well. [Trickster +1]
^Jaerd is a part of the Brotherhood of Clayworkers, capable of moulding and instructing Clay to do their bidding. [Clayworker + 1]
^<color=red>Warning: Changing tasks before finishing one is usually not well received.</color>

c-0: ^A strange claywork device, used to communicate with the City through Sigils of light and shadow.
^Your Ombrascope can gain you access to:

b: ^ - The interior of the ruins dotted around the City.

c-1: ^Pieces of strange machinery; their purpose unknown. All that matters is the useable clay inside.

c-0: ^Hardy workers, capable of following instructions but no use in a fight. Needed to scavenge for food and Clay.
c-1: ^Fighters and braves, armed with the skills and tools to fight both man and golem. Used to protect against danger.
c-2: ^Specialists used to interpret the City and its secrets. Always try to have at least one Shaman with you.
c-3: ^Specialists that mold Clay to do your bidding. Needed to turn Scrap into Clay, and for many other tasks in the City. Try to always have one with you.
c-4: ^Fayni comes from a family of traders, and has always had a way with words. Like you, she has never left the Corral. [Pactmaker +1]
c-5: ^Valfrig is a Shaman; sages, scientists, teachers and storytellers. His speciality is cartography - a lost art in the City. [Shamans +1]
c-6: ^Barr is one of the best, and bravest, warriors in the Corral. She will be able to advice you in all matters pertaining to War. [Warchief +1]
c-7: ^Jaerd is a part of the Brotherhood of Clayworkers, capable of moulding and instructing Clay to do their bidding. [Clayworker + 1]
c-8: ^Chi is a Wanderer; someone from outside the Elbéar tribe. Although a thief, she knows the world outside the Corral well. [Trickster +1]

b: ^<color=red>You must pick a Task before continuing!</color>

c-0: ^This on the other hand is test 01
^Your are an unknown in your tribe: your first task will be to build trust in your leadership. Lead a wercru, gather Tales of Bravery, and tell them to the Elders to build Trust!
^Build your legend until you are truly legendary!

s0: ^You order your wercru to a halt and consider your options.
s1: ^You stop in the shadow of a ruin. Your crew takes the opportunity to rest their legs.
s2: ^ You order a short rest, but tell your crew not to unpack yet.
s3: ^You take a short break. The wind picks up, howling between the buildings.
s4: ^You order a stop. Your wercru obeys, looking at you expectantly.

b: ^You have no wercru. You need to gather one if you are to survive out here.

s0: ^The members of your wercru groan in protest as you give the order to leave.
s1: ^Your wercru look like sleepwalkers as they start moving again, feet dragging along the pavement.
s2: ^Hope leaves the eyes of your wercru as they force themselves to move again.
s3: ^With visible effort, your wercru moves again.
s4: ^It is obvious your wercru had hoped for a longer rest. Their movements are slow and sluggish.

s0: ^You give the order to start moving again, and your crew sets off.
s1: ^You continue on your journey through the City.
s2: ^Time to go. Your crew hoists their packs and follows you.
s3: ^Your short rest is concluded, and soon your wercru is on its feet again.
s4: ^You get up, signalling to the others it’s time to go. Soon, you’re ready.

sendAwayCrew: ^Sometimes, you gather too big a crew, and some need to be sent away prematurely. This is frowned upon - especially if the tribesmen will have to make their way back to the Corral through dangerous land.

b: ^The tribesmen let go grumble as they leave. You have a feeling they will have something to say about your leadership when they reach the Corral.
^Your tribesmen say little as the selected ones pack their things and leave.
^Nevermind. You tell your wercru to get back to work.
^The warriors you selected to leave seem to take offense. You have a feeling they will not speak well of you once they reach the Corral.
^You hear some of the warriors taking credit for your acts of prowess as they leave. No doubt those tales will already long be told by the time you reach the Corral.
^The warriors you selected pack their things in silence and shame.
^Nevermind. You tell your wercru to get back to work.
^Your shamans are not amused. They have better things to do than get dragged around and then dropped.
^You have a feeling the shamans you let go will take credit for some of your acts.
^The shamans you selected take what few things they brought and leave without further ado.
^Nevermind. You tell your wercru to get back to work.
^Your clayworkers are not amused. They were promised certain things, and that promise is now broken.
^You have a feeling the Clayworkers will spread rumours about some of your acts, painting them in a much less favorable light.
^The clayworkers you selected pack what they brought and leave, back for the Corral.
^Nevermind. You tell your wercru to get back to work.
^Your clayworkers set about the task of turning the scrap you have looted into useable Clay. Soon the camp is wreathed in acrid smoke.
^You are no clayworker, but your father taught you well. Although it would be more effective with a trained clayworker...
^Your clayworkers finish their alchemy. Clean, new Clay, free of evil spirits.
^You finish your alchemy. Clean, new Clay, free of evil spirits.

manufactureClayDone: ^You marvel at the natural state of Clay - uniform black cubes, easily stacked. Each capable of marvels.

b: ^Your crew disperses into the Corral, to sleep the night with their families and friends. At least you will not have to worry about feeding them tonight.

s0: ^Your wercru, delirous with exhaustion, collapse into their tents. A silence falls over the camp within minutes.
s1: ^Your crew barely bother setting up their tents when the order comes to camp; some sleep in their cloaks right on the ground.
s2: ^You can hear sighs of relief throughout your crew, as they are finally given a chance to rest. Soon, the whole camp is still.
s3: ^People stagger to a stop when the order comes, practically swaying on their feet. Then they make camp with their last reserves of strength, before crawling into their tents to sleep.
s4: ^Exhausted beyond measure, your wercru rigs up their tents and crawl in to sleep. It takes moments before the first snores can be heard.

s0: ^Your wercru settles in for a rest from the never-ending walk, happy to rest their legs.
s1: ^Rest is always welcome. The crew chats amicably among themselves by their tents, and some even scavenge for some extra food around the camp.
s2: ^Soon, a campfire is lit, and someone is boiling some red tea. Everyone is glad for the chance to recuperate.
s3: ^The order to set up camp is greeted with a small cheer from your crew. They stop, and pitch tents with practiced ease.
s4: ^Your wercru is happy to stop and rest their weary legs. Tomorrow will be another day, but tonight it is time for sleep.

s0: ^Your wercru is slightly surprised at your order to stop and rest, but they are happy to comply. Soon, the tents are pitched – again.
s1: ^Some members of the crew protest – there is still more to be done – but they are quickly shushed by others, who are already happily pitching tents.
s2: ^Few of your crew are tired enough to sleep right away. Instead, they tell stories around the campfire. You listen in.
s3: ^Your wercru, although still fresh, is happy to comply. Someone makes a feast of it, gathering supplies for the soup from the surroundings.
s4: ^You give the order to stop and set up the tents. Your crew complies, always glad to rest.

s0: ^The people crawling from their tents are like new; revived once more after a good rest.
s1: ^You can tell from the atmosphere in the camp that the rest did more than good. Your wercru is once more ready to face the City.
s2: ^Despite some groaning, most seem to have recovered well. Soon, the camp is bustling with energy.
s3: ^After a long rest, your crew seems fully revived.

s0: ^You can tell your crew is far from well rested as they emerge from their tents. Hunger clearly gnaws at them.
s1: ^Sleep can only make you forget your hunger for so long; your crew, although rested, are clearly not in top form.
s2: ^Starting your day without breaking your fast leaves a mark. Your crew sits listlessly outside their tents, unsure of what to do.
s3: ^Your crew went to bed hungry and woke up hungry; the rest seems to have done little for their energy levels.
s4: ^The wercru crawling out of their tents hardly look any better rested than when they crawled in, their faces gaunt with hunger.

restDone: ^Your wercru has finished decamping and is ready to head out.

b:
^There is a sense of reverence as you settle down around the golden ombrascope. The moment you shine a light through it, you can see the image projected through it is no mere glyph: it moves.

^This is something different, and interpreting it will take time.
^You settle down in front of the golden ombrascope, ready to receive its guidance.

^The walls of the City fall away around you as you emerge into the park. For once, the sun can shine unimpeded from a clear sky, and as the members of your tribe pour out of the urban tunnels, each stops for a moment to take in the view. Your feet sink into the soft ground.

^Ahead of you lies the vine-jungle; calcified trees strangled by glowing genmod plants, reaching for the life-giving sun above. Deeper in lie the fertile Farms, where the Mealfruit grow, and the soft banks of the Anahita river, with its sweet waters.
^You are early: the vine-jungle stands like a wall before you, blocking your path.
^You are, however, already too late; the park is closed. Attendants buzz around, tending to the cut vines. One flies up to you, already flashing its warning message in glyphs. You cannot enter.
^The Eating Engine would simply have to wait.
^There are already paths cut through them, made by others who came before you.
^And somewhere in here lies the Eating Engine, and its cult. You just have to find it.

vineJungleNoPaths: ^Your tribesmen eagerly set to work cutting a path through the jungle. Being here this early means access to the sweetest fruit and the most unspoilt waters.
vineJunglePaths: ^You soon find a path left by another caravan of similar size to yours, and set down it.
vineJungleEncounters: ^The smell of the City disappears almost entirely in the jungle, replaced instead with the unfamiliar: bark, mulch, wet, rot.

s0: ^Apis the size of your fist cluster around the pungent-smelling flowers above your head, their wings beating faster than the eye can see.
s1: ^Likewise, the sound of the Wind itself is muffled between the living-dead trees, replaced with the rustle of vine-leaves.

s0: ^You hear a sudden cry of pain; a tribesman falls back from the side of the path, covered in his own blood. You never see what cut him, but by the time a healer reaches him he's already gone.
s1: ^A scout calls out the command to stop, and the whole caravan does. Something lumbers by, unseen, but not unheard; a Custodian, perhaps, or something else.

s0: ^The silence is interrupted by the sudden buzz of a hundred Apis, disturbed in their nests. They sweep down over the caravan, hard shells hitting like rocks. They are soon chased off, but not without leaving some bruises.
s1: ^You stay alert as you walk through the vine-jungle. You never know what might be out there. But nothing happens. Luckily.

vineJungleEncounters: ^Soon enough, you pass through the vine-jungle out into one of the clearings around the river Anahita.

s0: ^A Custodian lumbers by on the opposite side of the river, ignoring you.
s1: ^You see a clutch of Mealfruit bushes, just about to push themselves free of the ground.

b: ^You take a final look at your home of the last nearly two decades. It is the only place you have ever known. Beyond the chain-link fence lies the City, in all its mystery and awe. To survive it will require everything you have learned.
^Your arrival causes a stir through the Corral. Everyone is eager to hear about your adventures.
^Tell your crew they can return to their families. (You must reform your crew before leaving)
^Tell your crew to wait outside; you are only visiting briefly. (-1

c-1: ^You are the crew chief – they must do what you ask. But there is grumbling; this is highly irregular.
c-2: ^They look at you as you enter through the Corral gates, mumbling and talking amongst themselves. What happened to your crew?

b: ^They look at you as you enter through the Corral gates, mumbling and talking amongst themselves. What happened to your crew? And so soon? Whatever the truth, it sets people talking.

s0: ^The main 'street' of the Corral is blocked by a couple arguing about whose cow should back off first.
s1: ^A litter of kids run out between two tents, laughing and hitting each other with sticks.
s2: ^A group of children are listening to a Shaman telling the oral history of the tribe.
s3: ^It is nearly time for dinner. The smell of baking root-bread drifts through the air and makes your mouth water.
s4: ^A Clayworker is entertaining some farmers on a break with a puppet show. You're not sure what the plot is, but the farmers laugh.

b: ^There is a crowd in the Crupit again, although you feel there are fewer who are simply curious, and more who are serious – if they can be convinced.
^The Pitchief looks at you - crew-less - and frowns. Not even a week has passed since you last stood inside the Crupit, yet here you are without a single tribesman left in your crew?
^Beg to be allowed to re-form a crew.
^You enter the Crupit again, but the Pitchief chases you out.
^You have your wercru. Come back after you’ve done your work.

reformcrewEarly: ^Very well. But wercrus are not disposable things: as cruchief you have a responsibility..

b: ^'First, you must tell us what you intend to do.'
^'Still working on the same thing, hm? Better luck this  time, I suppose...'
^The throng of interested fill up the crupit with the hum of talk.
^A fair crowd remains in the crupit.
^Only a few clumps of interested remain.
^There is a real crowd in the crupit, all here to hear your words.
^It is not hard to find volunteers, despite the dangers. Soon, you have a selection of fine young tribesmen, ready to head out.
^The young braves jostle each other in their eagerness to be first in line.
^The gathered clayworkers discuss, and then one steps forward as a volunteer.
^One shaman steps up, convinced by your speech.
^The tales told to entice them, however, you will not get back.
^Despite your best efforts, the tribesmen do not seem convinced, although some do sign up.
^Your words are clearly not impressing the young braves. Most turn away.
^None of the clayworkers seem convinced. One by one, they turn away.
^The shamans listen politely, but when all is said and done, no-one seems interested in joining.
^The worst part is, the tales you told you entice them were not even believed.

^Every wercru is given enough supplies for a few days, in whatever form is the easiest to carry. Dried rootbread, beef jerky, sunfruit, sunfruit seeds…whatever is in season, and whatever the Quartermasters can spare.
^The Quartermaster gives you a confused look.
^'Unless you have a wercru, I can’t give you your wercu rations.'

c-0: ^'No exceptions just because of your blood.' The quartermaster says. 'And no more than your need.' He begins a headcount.

b: ^Under his watchful eyes, your whole party is soon resupplied. You are last. As you leave, he wishes you a quiet ‘good luck’.
^'You’ve enough already, I should think.' He sends out away without further ceremony.
^The quartermaster turns you away. You have already received your rations.

s1: ^You catch your grandmother at the tail-end of a dirty joke.
s2: ^There seems to be no-one there, until you realize they are all napping behind the benches.
s3: ^They look up as you arrive, smiling.

c-0: ^You sit down and share the stories of your exploits. The Elders listen attentively. You know they will spread them onwards.
c-1: ^The Elders laugh. They gasp. They cheer. Everyone loves a story where a good trick wins the day.
c-2: ^The Elders listen quietly. Afterwards they mumble and nod amongst themselves. You can see your grandmother nod proudly at you.
c-3: ^The Elders cannot help but nod along, impressed despite themselves at your feats of diplomacy and wordcraft.
c-4: ^You return with tidings of your most recent successes.

loc_Corral: ^You need to get the Sigil from the gate first!
loc_Ruins_Interior: ^As you attempt to enter, walls spring out of nowhere, blocking your path. A clay-light appears, waiting for a sigil that you do not have.
loc_Stacks_Interior: ^As you attempt to enter, walls spring out of nowhere, blocking your path. A clay-light appears, waiting for a sigil that you do not have.
loc_Center: ^A wall of turrets pops up in front of you. Best not risk it.

dangerhuman: ^They give you no time to parlay and attack!
^You tell your warriors to act as scouts to help everyone sneak past them safely.
^You decide to attempt to parlay; albeit carrying a big stick.

b: ^You manage to sneak past them without alerting them to your presence.
^A call goes up from the group! You order everyone to run. Did everyone make it...?

dangerhumanLoseTrickster: ^A call goes up from the group! You order everyone to run

b: ^while you drop some supplies to distract them

dangerhumanLoseTrickster: ^You later regroup, out of breath, but safe.
dangerhumanLoseWarchief: ^During the fight, some of their number slip past your defences and

b: ^You manage to convince them you are not worth the fight, and your two parties part way peacefully.
^In the middle of the talk someone throws a rock, and it sudenly turns into a scuffle - several heads bashed in later, you mutually back away.

dangerhumanlosePactmaker: ^Despite your best attempt, the confrontation turns hostile!
dangercity: ^It notices you, and attacks without mercy.
^You can create an interference shield from Clay - provided you have enough...and enough Clayworkers.
^You attempt to parlay, your shamans acting as interpreters.

b: ^but you and your warriors come out of it mostly intact.

dangercityWinWarchief: ^Now to escape before the City sends out its Hunter-Killers.
dangercityLoseWarchief: ^You do not have time to bury your dead after.
dangercityWinTrickster: ^Your ploy works; the City's eye passes over you - and then beyond. You wait under your shields for a while, and then continue;

b: ^ although not all the Clay could be re-used.

dangercityLoseTrickster: ^The ploy almost works, but then the City's agents see through your shields. You order everyone to run.

b: ^ Luckily, the City seems more interested in observing the shields you left behind.

dangercityLoseTrickster: ^You escape somewhere safer, regrouping as best you can.

b: ^ You present the correct permits, or quickly manufacture them on the spot. The City scans you with its clay-light, and then, to your relief, leaves.
^The City looks at your united front and - for a second - seems to give you the green light. And then, the bloodshed starts. You run.

dangercityWinPactmaker: ^You eventually get far enough away for the City to forget you.
dangercityLosePactmaker: ^You attempt to present the permits, but every word you speak and sigil you display seems to anger the City more. Shrill warning sirens follow red clay-light.

b: ^ A shaman disappears in a shower of red, and the attack is on.
^The attack comes as a complete surprise.
^Lacking a wercru, you keep entirely to yourself, not risking as much as meeting a fellow traveller. You will need to get back and find a new wercru soon.

eventgeneric_1: ^You spot a dot in the sky, heralding the arrival of one of the City's Overseers. This is an old one, covered in mossbeard and mold. It has not yet seen you.
^Order your wercru to lay low and hide.
^Prepare to recite the Words of Notice.

b: ^You find a crevice between two buildings where everyone fits. The old Overseer circles the area in a lazy patrol, before leaving.

^You do not do a very good job of finding cover, your limbs heavy and your minds clouded. The Overseer very nearly catches you, despite being old and decripit, its light-of-challenge flickers on and off intermittently. After a long time, it finally leaves, and you breathe a sigh of relief.

c-1: ^You stand tall as the Overseer circles. It takes a moment for it to spot you. When it does, it lowers itself in front of you, unsteady, and turns on its light-of-challenge. In the language of the Bozes, it shouts a challenge at you.

b: ^You calmly recite the standard reply. The Overseer wobbles in the air for a moment, before shutting off its light and hovering off. Your crew waits until it is gone before cheering.

^You attempt to recite the standard reply: you know it, by heart. But a fog of exhaustion makes the words stumble out of your mouth. The Overseer wobbles. Then it shouts its challenge again, its eye turning red. Fear makes you concentrate, and you repeat yourself, louder, even as the Overseer rises above you, its challenge-light hopping from crew-member to crew-member. After a heart-stopping second, it accepts your words. It turns off its light and hovers off.

^You recite the words as you learned them, your voice breaking slightly. The Overseer wobbles. Then it shouts its challenge again, its eye turning red. You repeat yourself, louder, even as the Overseer rises above you, its challenge-light hopping from crew-member to crew-member. After a heart-stopping second, it accepts youe words. It turns off its light and hovers off.

c-2: ^The Overseer is old; it may not respond to the Words of Notice as expected.
^ The goal is to destroy it before it can inform the Bozes, if it comes to it.

b: ^The Overseer circles your position a few times, but it does not notice you. After a tense few minutes, it flies off.

^As the old Overseer circles, time and again, your attention wanes; exhaustion overtakes you, and you close your eyes. For just a second. When your wercru wakes you, the Overseer is gone; and so is their respect.

g-0: ^The Overseer finally gone, you continue on your way.

eventgeneric_2: ^A sudden sound of something cracking, followed by a yelp and a thud interrupts your walk. A hole has suddenly appeared in the pavement, a clean crack that leads down into some unknown area underneath. And one of your wercru has fallen in.
^You hurry up to the crack, carefully crawling the last bit to look down. The face of a
^ looks up at you. They report being mostly unharmed, but it is clear there is no way to climb up easily.
^Have your Clayworkers fashion a quick rescue rope. (
^Fashion a rope out of whatever material you find handy.
^Tell them you will send someone else to get them. (

b: ^It does not take long to fashion a rope out of Clay. It is thin, but can easily carry a man. Together, you brace as the
^ climbs out. Afterwards, most of the clay in the rope is reused.

^Your clayworker, in a haze of exhaustion, finally finishes the rope. It looks thin - too thin. But the clayworker assures you it will hold. You drop it down and brace, but halfway up the rope snaps! You rush to the edge, but you can immediately tell your
^ was not as lucky this time.

^Your clayworker finishes the rope after some time. It seems thick and sturdy, but for some reason your clayworker is not happy. You drop the rope down and brace. It holds well, and after a moment your
^ is back on solid ground. A few moments later, the claywork rope begins to harden, turning into a brittle, dusty substance. The clayworker in charge curses under his breath.

c-1: ^It takes a bit of time, but soon you have a sturdy enough rope. You drop it into the hole.

b: ^ soon finishes climbing up the hole. You haul them up the last bit yourself. They dust themselves off, thanking you for your help.
^ is nearly at the top when their hand slips off the rope material. Or perhaps they were too tired to hold on. You rush to the edge of the hole and look down. Your
^ lies sprawled in an unnatural angle, neck broken.
^Your wercru immediately protests. You do not leave your own behind. You can sense real anger in their eyes.
^You explain the urgency of your mission; why there is no time to waste. They do not like what they hear, but they grudgingly accept it.
^You try to explain to them why there is no time to waste - when that fails, you resort to the law of the wercru. You are the leader, they must listen to you. Despite that, a
^ says they will stay behind just in case. There is nothing you can do to convince them otherwise.

eventgeneric_3: ^You take a short break in the shadow of a building, careful not to touch it but enjoying the shade it provides. As you do, you notice two of your crew members cannot stop arguing; you cannot decide if they are siblings, lovers, former lovers, great friends, terrible friends, or utter strangers to one another - but their mutual sniping is beginning to grate. And not just on you.
^Listen to both, and try to figure out a compromise. (
^Listen to both and determine who is right and who is wrong. (
^Ask them to keep their rivalry to themselves while on the road. (

c-0: ^Compromise, as the Elders say, means finding a solution where everyone is equally miserable. You listen to both of them.

s0: ^They are siblings, fighting over some obscure old slight from when they were both toddlers.
s1: ^They are former lovers, rekindling an old argument.
s2: ^They are good friends but incredibly thick-headed, and their good-natured argument risks going sour.
s3: ^They are lovers, both angry that the other one decided to volunteer.
s4: ^They pretend friendship, yet they clearly detest one another.
s5: ^They slept together last night, and now neither can decide if that was a mistake or not.
s6: ^They are natural grumps, attracted to each other like Vultures to scrap.

b: ^Somehow, you manage to make them bridge their differences, joining together in a mutual dislike of you instead. Success?
^Half-way through your talk, you lose your line of thought. So do they. Soon, they return to their bickering, except they seem even more entrenched than before.

^You try to get them to compromise, but your efforts lead to nothing but their fighting becoming more intense, somehow both of them being sure you are on their side. Finally, you have to physically separate them.
^When it is time to go again, one of the two - a
^ - is nowhere to be found, their pack gone. You wait for a while, but it is clear they are not coming back. At least your crew is now quiet.
^The physical fight seems to have been catharsis of a kind at least, and for the first time in a while they are quiet. But the mood in the wercru is not wonderful.

c-1: ^You let each of them air their grievances to you.

b: ^Acting like a neutral arbiter, you determine who is more correct. The winner gloats over the loser; but at least the camp is quiet again.
